verses.verse: So I returned <S%H7725><s%>, and considered <S%H7200><s%> all the oppressions <S%H6217><s%> that are done <S%H6213><s%> under the sun <S%H8121><s%>: and behold the tears <S%H1832><s%> of such as were oppressed <S%H6231><s%>, and they had no comforter <S%H5162><s%>; and on the side <S%H3027><s%> of their oppressors <S%H6231><s%> there was power <S%H3581><s%>; but they had no comforter <S%H5162><s%>.
Wherefore I praised <S%H7623><s%> the dead <S%H4191><s%> which are already <S%H3528><s%> dead <S%H4191><s%> more than the living <S%H2416><s%> which are yet <S%H5728><s%> alive <S%H2416><s%>.

Yea, better <S%H2896><s%> is he than both <S%H8147><s%> they, which hath not yet <S%H5728><s%> been, who hath not seen <S%H7200><s%> the evil <S%H7451><s%> work <S%H4639><s%> that is done <S%H6213><s%> under the sun <S%H8121><s%>.

¶ Again, I considered <S%H7200><s%> all travail <S%H5999><s%>, and every right <S%H3788><s%> work <S%H4639><s%>, that for this a man <S%H376><s%> is envied <S%H7068><s%> of his neighbour <S%H7453><s%>. This is also vanity <S%H1892><s%> and vexation <S%H7469><s%> of spirit <S%H7307><s%>.
The fool <S%H3684><s%> foldeth <S%H2263><s%> his hands <S%H3027><s%> together <S%H2263><s%>, and eateth <S%H398><s%> his own flesh <S%H1320><s%>.

Better <S%H2896><s%> is an handful <S%H3709><s%> with quietness <S%H5183><s%>, than both the hands <S%H2651><s%> full <S%H4393><s%> with travail <S%H5999><s%> and vexation <S%H7469><s%> of spirit <S%H7307><s%>.
¶ Then I returned <S%H7725><s%>, and I saw <S%H7200><s%> vanity <S%H1892><s%> under the sun <S%H8121><s%>.

There is <S%H3426><s%> one <S%H259><s%> alone, and there is not a second <S%H8145><s%>; yea, he hath neither child <S%H1121><s%> nor brother <S%H251><s%>: yet is there no end <S%H7093><s%> of all his labour <S%H5999><s%>; neither is his eye <S%H5869><s%> satisfied <S%H7646><s%> with riches <S%H6239><s%>; neither saith he, For whom do I labour <S%H6001><s%>, and bereave <S%H2637><s%> my soul <S%H5315><s%> of good <S%H2896><s%>? This is also vanity <S%H1892><s%>, yea, it is a sore <S%H7451><s%> travail <S%H6045><s%>.
¶ Two <S%H8147><s%> are better <S%H2896><s%> than one <S%H259><s%>; because they have <S%H3426><s%> a good <S%H2896><s%> reward <S%H7939><s%> for their labour <S%H5999><s%>.

For if they fall <S%H5307><s%>, the one <S%H259><s%> will lift up <S%H6965><s%> his fellow <S%H2270><s%>: but woe <S%H337><s%> to him that is alone <S%H259><s%> when he falleth <S%H5307><s%>; for he hath not another <S%H8145><s%> to help him up <S%H6965><s%>.
Again <S%H1571><s%>, if two <S%H8147><s%> lie together <S%H7901><s%>, then they have heat <S%H2552><s%>: but how can one <S%H259><s%> be warm <S%H3179><s%> alone?

And if one <S%H259><s%> prevail <S%H8630><s%> against him, two <S%H8147><s%> shall withstand <S%H5975><s%> him; and a threefold <S%H8027><s%> cord <S%H2339><s%> is not quickly <S%H4120><s%> broken <S%H5423><s%>.

¶ Better <S%H2896><s%> is a poor <S%H4542><s%> and a wise <S%H2450><s%> child <S%H3206><s%> than an old <S%H2205><s%> and foolish <S%H3684><s%> king <S%H4428><s%>, who will <S%H3045><s%> no more be admonished <S%H2094><s%>.
For out of prison <S%H631><s%> <S%H1004><s%> he cometh <S%H3318><s%> to reign <S%H4427><s%>; whereas also he that is born <S%H3205><s%> in his kingdom <S%H4438><s%> becometh poor <S%H7326><s%>.

I considered <S%H7200><s%> all the living <S%H2416><s%> which walk <S%H1980><s%> under the sun <S%H8121><s%>, with the second <S%H8145><s%> child <S%H3206><s%> that shall stand up <S%H5975><s%> in his stead.

There is no end <S%H7093><s%> of all the people <S%H5971><s%>, even of all that have been before <S%H6440><s%> them: they also that come after <S%H314><s%> shall not rejoice <S%H8055><s%> in him. Surely this also is vanity <S%H1892><s%> and vexation <S%H7475><s%> of spirit <S%H7307><s%>.
